text: now eu leaders are meeting for a two-day
summit in the shadow of a deepening
dispute with member state poland a top
polish court recently found certain
parts of eu law were incompatible with
its own constitution a ruling that's
been described as a direct challenge to
the bloc's legal order jessica parker
explains the tensions from brussels
there isn't necessarily going to be
unanimity here over what to do what many
people agree here at least in brussels
from the kind of brussels perspective
is that ruling from poland's
constitutional court opposes something
of an existential crisis to the legal
bedrock of the european union and
therefore something has to be done
about it that's certainly a view you
hear regularly here in brussels although
mateusz morievsky are very insistent
when he spoke earlier in the week that
the ruling had been misunderstood even
suggesting there were examples of powers
from the european union via court
rulings overreaching into a national
boundaries but as eu leaders meet here
this evening uh it's interesting to note
that the rule of law crisis as some
people have dubbed it wasn't even an
official item on the agenda it will be
touched upon uh we're told by
the president of the council charles
michelle we don't really know how much
that conversations they all sit around a
table will take off and could even get
heated
or whether there'll be a sense that
actually they don't want this to
completely overshadow things here they
also want to talk about for example
migration and the surge in energy prices
so there are big topics that are
officially actually on the agenda that
leaders will want to get to as well yeah
fascinating and i wonder jessica whether
this uh this latest row is because it's
just happened in the in the last week or
so it's a new item on the agenda rather
than kind of as you say now allowing it
to dominate uh the whole summit
yeah so it was interesting yesterday
charles michelle released his sort of
invitation uh letter something of a
formality but it was there he
acknowledged that the rule of law
although he didn't specifically name
poland would be
touched upon and i think that is partly
because some people were really pushing
it some nations were really pushing for
it to be a disgust they didn't think the
matter could be ignored others probably
less keen because they don't want the
summit uh to be overshadowed and i think
what will be very important as well is
clearly the things that angela merkel
the outgoing german chancellor has to
say this is
likely although not certainly but likely
to be her a last summit as german
chancellor she's clocked up something
like 107 in her many years in office but
she has been urging a more conciliatory
approach really trying to dial down the
rhetoric because things did get pretty
heated earlier in the week
that was jessica parker there now the
president of the european commission was
heading into the meeting just a few
minutes ago and she did list that
dispute with poland as the first topic
leaders will be addressing today have
listen
this is not new this is an ongoing
process
but with the recent ruling of the
constitutional court this has taken a
new dimension so i'm looking forward to
the discussions with the leaders
we all have to take a responsibility
when it comes to protecting our
fundamental values
